awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Ecological and Evolutionary Forces Reshaping Mutualism During Species Introductions
awd_abstract_narration:
Introduced species can wreak havoc on ecosystems by displacing natives and by altering environmental conditions. While much is known about the properties of invasive plants and animals, much less is known about the beneficial microbes (microscopic organisms) that accompany introduced species. Rhizobia are beneficial bacteria that inhabit leguminous plant root tissue where they convert nitrogen from the atmosphere to a plant-available form. Leguminous plants provide these microbes with sugars from photosynthesis. Legumes that disperse to habitats that lack these bacteria are typically unable to persist, however the bacteria can also spread through the soil or air. The aim of this research is to examine whether invasions change the nature of a mutualistic interaction.  The investigators will study specialization and the evolution of cooperation in both natural and experimentally staged invasions for two plant species and their beneficial microbes. While this question has been addressed in aboveground systems, this is one of the first to utilize a belowground plant mutualism. This project will promote diversity in the sciences, provide research training and education in the biology of plant-microbe interactions, and inform efforts to control invasive plants. Diverse undergraduate students from Florida International University will participate in summer research at University of California at Riverside and Michigan State University. An educational module will also be developed on rhizobium-legume interactions in neighborhood soils, to be distributed to school children via MSU's Kellogg Biological Station Bioenergy Sustainability Program and the Fairchild Challenge, an environmental education program that reaches over 100,000 children a year in Miami.

To understand whether mutualisms become less beneficial in the process of species invasions, this project will test the hypothesized trade-off between partner breadth and mutualism benefit across legume and rhizobium genotypes from the native and invasive range for two Medicago species. Medicago is the genus that includes alfalfa. Both species are native to Europe and invasive in the US. The researchers will 1) compare genetic diversity in native vs. invaded host range mutualists, using high marker density genotyping for hosts and whole-genome sequencing for symbionts, 2) assess divergence in mutualism properties between the native and invaded range to test hypotheses of reduced specialization, partner choice and mutualism dependence in invaded range mutualists using cross-inoculation trials, 3) test the impact of invasion on symbiont genome dynamics and mutualisms by simulated symbiont invasions in soil mesocosms under contrasting host density and diversity, and 4) identify the molecular underpinnings of mutualism specialization using a transcriptomic approach to nominate host-symbiont pathways. This research will shed light on the long-standing question of whether beneficial microbes face a trade-off between having a broad partner range and providing a high degree of benefit to a partner.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The project made an extensive collection of Medicago polymorpha and Medicao lupulina and their rhizobial symbionts in  both their native range (Western Europe) and invaded range (North America). We characterized the genetic variation in the collections of Medicago polymorpha and associated Ensifer medicae and Ensifer meliloti strains through genotyping by sequencing (plant) and whole genome sequencing (rhizobia). North American populations of M. polymorpha showed a similar geographic cline in flowering time as native range populations, despite their reduced genetic diversity. Sanger sequencing and phylogenomic analysis of a subset of these strains revealed that, contrary to expectation, the invaded range populations did not undergo a genetic bottleneck but rather contain as much diversity as the wild range. We developed a high-throughput fluorescent nodule phenotyping method and developed imageJ scripts for semi-automated analysis. Prior to the COVID19 shutdown, we worked diligently to label the wild Ensifer with fluourescent plasmids to carry out partner choice assays.

We also explored the relationship between symbionts and antagonists under invasion. Herbivore assays demonstrated that invaded range genotypes are unpreferred by a herbivore that occurs in the invaded range, showing that M. polymorpha has evolved during the course of invasion. Microplate scale biochemical assays were developed to measure herbivore-relevant molecular signatures in leaves and collect data on constitutive and induced defenses across our collection. Evolutionary modeling of tripartite interactions and found contrasting dynamics depending on the architecture of the interaction, corresponding to the popular enemy release versus biotic resistance hypotheses. Finally, we found that rhizobia can protect against soil-borne antagonists through inoculation experiments.

Intellectual Merit: The project found evidence of contemporary evolution in herbivory and phenological traits as well as symbiotic traits in Medicago polymorpha during the invasion of North America. We developed high-throughput marker systems and molecular assays for these two important interactions, which could be used more widely by the ecological community. We gathered data that gives insight into the invasion history and patterns of genetic diversity within host and symbiont, suggestive of multiple invasions and high symbiont dispersal rates, which has implications for other host-symbiont invasions.

Broader Impacts: This project contributed to training 12 undergraduates (9 female, 3 non-Caucasian females; including 2 REUs), 2 graduate students (both female), 3 postdocs (including Dr. Jack, an African-American female), and 5 technicians (3 female) in evolutionary ecology, microbiology, and molecular biology / genomics at MSU and WSU Pullman. The project also resulted in a novel germplasm collection of paired plants and symbionts from across Western Europe and North America. Understanding how mutualisms evolve during contemporary time, particularly the extent to which invading novel habitats imposes selection for reductions in mutualistic behavior, is of great potential importance since many ecosystem services depend upon mutualisms, including nitrogen-fixation. Furthermore, agriculture is essentially human-mediated species range expansion on a massive scale, and so better understanding the selection pressures and potential responses of mutualistic plant-microbe interactions could inform breeding strategies.


Last Modified: 04/24/2022
Modified by: Maren L Friesen
